Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to allow for arbitration of pension claims that remain unresolved after review. Participants or beneficiaries can request arbitration within 60 days of receiving notice of the completion of the review process. The amended Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows for arbitration of unresolved pension claims. A request for arbitration constitutes a waiver of other review rights. The arbitration process will be fair and equitable, with arbitrators selected by the Secretary. Costs of arbitration, including fees, may be assessed by the arbitrator, not exceeding $500 per party. Prevailing participants may receive attorney's fees and pre-judgment interest. The amended Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows for arbitration of unresolved pension claims. The arbitration award may include attorney's fees, pre-judgment interest, and punitive damages for willful misconduct. Arbitration proceedings will be conducted similarly to those under title 9, United States Code, with limited appeal rights. The amended Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows for arbitration of unresolved pension claims. A party aggrieved by the arbitrator's award may bring an action in a United States district court to vacate or modify the award within 30 days. The district courts have exclusive jurisdiction over such actions, and the court may award costs and attorney's fees to the prevailing party. The amended Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows for arbitration of unresolved pension claims. A party aggrieved by the arbitrator's award may bring an action in a United States district court within 30 days. The court may award costs and attorney's fees to the prevailing party. The Secretary must be served a copy of the complaint in any action under this paragraph by certified mail. The Secretary may intervene in such action. The table of contents in the Act is amended to reflect these changes. The amendments in Section 503 of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allow for arbitration of pension claims. These amendments apply to claims arising after the enactment of this Act. Additionally, pre-judgment interest on unpaid benefits and punitive damages for willful misconduct are addressed in Section 3. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for pre-judgment interest on unpaid pension benefits and attorney fees for prevailing participants or beneficiaries in pension plan actions. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 now allows for attorney's fees, expert witness fees, and other costs for prevailing participants or beneficiaries in pension plan actions. Additionally, punitive damages may be awarded for willful misconduct by plan sponsors, administrators, or fiduciaries. The amendments made by this section allow for punitive damages in addition to other remedies for participants or beneficiaries in pension plan actions. Effective date applies to causes of action arising after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. ANNUAL REPORTS TO PARTICIPANTS AND BENEFICIARIES IN UNDERSTANDABLE LANGUAGE. Section 104(b) of ERISA is amended to require plan administrators to provide participants and beneficiaries with statements, schedules, and reports on plan investments, trustee information, and trustee selection methods within 210 days after each plan year. The amended Section 104(b) of ERISA mandates plan administrators to furnish participants and beneficiaries with detailed information on plan investments, trustee selection, and long-term solvency evaluation, including benefit projections for future plan years. Additionally, the report must include any necessary material to summarize the latest annual report and provide information on where participants and beneficiaries can seek assistance regarding the plan. The plan administrator must provide easily understandable and accurate information to plan participants and beneficiaries about their rights and obligations under the plan. Copies of the plan description, annual report, and relevant agreements must be available for examination, and upon request, the administrator must provide copies of reports and agreements to participants and beneficiaries. The plan administrator must provide participants and beneficiaries with information about their rights and obligations under the plan, including copies of relevant agreements. Amendments to the Act require administrators to furnish specific information to participants and beneficiaries as outlined in sections 104(b)(1) and 105(a) and (c). Amendments to the Act include redesignating paragraphs and updating sections related to the furnishing of reports and materials to participants and beneficiaries. Amendments made to the Act require the provision of necessary materials to participants and beneficiaries. Effective starting January 1, 1998.
